since_last_update: Weekend headline risk re-entered the tape: President Trump threatened a 100% tariff on Canadian goods tied to Canada’s China trade deal, raising renewed trade-policy/geopolitical risk premia into the Sunday reopen (AP, Washington Post).

Shutdown risk is back on the near-term calendar: U.S. government funding deadline is Friday Jan 30, 2026, with reporting around a bipartisan funding path but still political friction around DHS/ICE provisions (Washington Post).

Setup has shifted toward a ‘macro + mega-cap earnings + Fed’ convergence week: a heavy Magnificent-7 earnings slate and a Fed decision mid-week are being framed as the dominant near-term catalysts for index direction and factor leadership (Reuters via Investing.com; Economic Times/Reuters).
today_focus: Dominant driver check (today/Sunday reopen): policy-risk premium from trade headlines (Trump-Canada tariff threat) is the clearest incremental weekend input; watch for risk-off gap dynamics (ES/NQ softer) and gold bid if headline escalates (AP, Washington Post).

Macro driver this session: “Fed week” positioning—market sensitivity likely higher to rates/real-yield repricing than to single-point data, given valuation/mega-cap concentration; gold’s near-term direction likely hinges on real-rate vs risk-off dominance (Economic Times/Reuters; MarketWatch).

Earnings as the near-term differentiator: with a large share of index weight reporting, guidance (AI capex, margins, demand elasticity) can drive NQ vs ES divergence even if the macro tape is stable (Economic Times/Reuters).

Funding/shutdown optics: headline-driven volatility risk rises as the Jan 30 deadline approaches; even ‘averted shutdown’ progress can still produce intraday whipsaws via risk-on relief then fade (Washington Post).

market_pricing.dominant_narrative: Policy-risk premium (trade/shutdown) layered on top of Fed-week + mega-cap earnings; rates/real-yield sensitivity remains the key transmission channel for US equity duration and gold.
what_markets_seem_to_be_pricing: Base case remains: Fed holds rates at the upcoming meeting; the bigger pricing lever is the tone on inflation progress and the implied path for 2026 easing vs patience (Economic Times/Reuters).

Earnings bar is high given elevated index concentration/valuation framing; markets appear positioned to reward confirmation of AI-driven profit leverage and punish any capex/margin disappointment (Economic Times/Reuters).
Gold demand narrative remains supported by ‘policy/geopolitics/fiscal’ bid plus ETF/central bank flows, but near-term swings still likely dominated by real-rate/risk sentiment impulses (MarketWatch).
underpriced_risks: Binary policy headline risk: tariff rhetoric can translate into immediate risk-premium repricing before any formal action; correlation spikes and liquidity gaps are plausible around the reopen (AP, Washington Post).
Shutdown tail: even if a deal is likely, timing/legislative friction can reprice front-end risk and volatility quickly into the Jan 30 deadline (Washington Post).
Index concentration risk: a small number of mega-cap reports can overwhelm broader ‘earnings beat rate’ and drive outsized NQ/ES dispersion (Economic Times/Reuters).

risk_register.risk: Trade-policy escalation (Trump 100% tariff threat vs Canada) triggers risk-off repricing; potential spillover into inflation expectations and rates volatility.
Government funding/shutdown brinkmanship creates late-week volatility and gap risk into the Jan 30 deadline.
risk_register.timeframe: This week, peaking Thu–Fri (Jan 29–30, 2026) and into the weekend

risk_register.risk: Fed communication surprises (hawkish hold / inflation caution) lift real yields and pressure equity duration; alternatively, dovish tilt boosts duration but may weaken USD and support gold.
Mega-cap earnings/guidance drives factor rotation and NQ vs ES divergence; single-name shocks propagate to index level.
Gold whipsaw risk if policy headlines push risk-off while real yields move the other direction; short-horizon correlation instability.

event_warnings: Fri Jan 30, 2026: U.S. government funding deadline—shutdown risk and headline volatility likely to rise into the close and over the weekend (Washington Post).

This week: Fed decision (mid-week) + dense mega-cap earnings—expect higher sensitivity to guidance and to Powell tone; index moves may be narrow/weight-driven rather than broad (Economic Times/Reuters).
Mon Jan 26, 2026: U.S. durable goods (headline + core) — potential rates impulse if prints challenge the ‘soft-landing’ or inflation narrative (calendar input).
Tue Jan 27, 2026: CB Consumer Confidence + Richmond Fed — can move growth sentiment and front-end rates at the margin (calendar input).
Ongoing: watch for follow-through/details on Trump’s Canada tariff threat; any formal steps (not just rhetoric) would likely be treated as a regime escalation (AP, Washington Post).
